If you are in the Joint ventures or subsidiaries,  it's even worse. Turn over is high and morale is low.

Many organization changes now and management is not transparent to employees on the impact that will be coming or maybe they don't have a clue on exactly what is happening especially in the middle management and down.

Pay is below market norm.

job_title: Systems Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I worked in systems at Boeing as a systems integrator for various programs. A few things really stood out to me. High priority was put on the employee/leadership relationship. I cannot remember a time when my manager did not have his or her door open for me to discuss career development, compensation, and workplace satisfaction. If meetings were to be rescheduled, it was done so with prompt notice and not at the last second. I was also exposed to a wide variety of hardware and software. For those who are looking to advance their careers on either of those fronts, systems integration is a great place to get started!
cons: This is not your "typical" engineering job. For those that want to do advanced design or analysis, this career path likely isn't for you. The role follows a model where the product design is mostly complete, with slight modifications needing to be added or taken away based on customer needs. Integration roles also routinely require people to be in labs, working hands on with equipment. The biggest negative of this role is that it's difficult to say the employee can maintain a schedule where working from home is consistent, even in today's far more flexible day in age.

pros: Great opportunities to do overtime and make extra money. My area is pretty good in the sense that the work is consistent and easy to learn over time and the crew is very supportive, both other inspectors and mechanics. The people really make or break the day, luckily I'm with a crew who are fun to be around and we all help each other out when the day gets busy.
cons: Occasional bad apples in management pushing for numbers and attempting to cut corners so that their number sheet looks good to their higher ups. Need to be mindful of how they interact with you as they could be subtly attempting to coerce you to buy off work that clearly isn't completed yet. Butting heads between different shifts, mostly 1st and 2nd.

pros: It’s pretty simple, just be there on time, do your work and leave.

review_title: General Electric strangles another company to death

Forced stack ranking of bottom 10% of employees, outsourcing entire groups (including engineering) and functions, moving entire teams to other states. Leadership is entirely focused on their next quarters bonuses and will be leaving before major impacts are visible to their short term cost cutting. Leaders are not from Boeing and do not care about the people that work here. Are there development projects or are the current designs being milked into oblivion, with no future?  Meanwhile Airbus and new competitors will continue to take market share. Thus experienced analysts, low and mid tier managers are leaving for greener pastures.

Management doesn't seem to care, and if they do its misplaced on the wrong things as a result of likely blindly following those above them. I have lost a lot of trust and faith in the decisions this company now makes. It's those closest to the product who have the most care for quality and innovation, but the influence of leadership's concern with budgets, optics, and anything related to the stock poisons the efforts of those at the bottom by limiting their ability to pursue the things that will ultimately save this company in the long run.

job_title: Electrical Engineer II in El Segundo, CA
pros: Lots of opportunities for growth. The entire El Segundo site is very busy and has been for a while, and engineers are expected to tackle projects that may be above their pay grade. Many projects are high-visibility and can lead to upper-management recognition if completed successfully. Paperwork, process, and red-tape can be frustrating, but the culture at the El Segundo site is not a typical "slow-paced defense company culture". The work can be challenging and engaging depending on the team you are on. All together, the pay/benefits are solid for the area. The base pay may be lower than some competitors, but once the healthcare costs/contributions, retirement contributions, overtime pay, and bonus (depends on year) are factored in, the pay can be good! PTO accrual is very generous, but it is frequently a challenge to get the opportunity to use it with project timelines. On-site gyms in the SoCal area are nice, but often crowded at peak times.
cons: Burn-out is common due to aggressive timelines on certain teams within the site, especially when supporting projects needed for production.

review_title: Management Can Overrule HR & Demand Your "Obedience"
pros: Benefits & pay - the only reason Boeing management has employees to neglect. At first, it seems like Boeing pays well, but if you take a step back and look at the entire picture, you can easily see that you are underpaid, overworked, and undervalued. Being salaried at $60k+ starting out looks and sounds great, but you are only salaried IF it benefits Boeing, meaning: if you work 75 hours during the pay period, you are only paid for 75 hours, but if you work 90+ hours during the pay period, you are only paid for 80 hours, no overtime - this was a first, I'm salary and I clock in and out. Working remote was a pro, but the higher-ups have made it clear that they are going to get rid of that possibility: management informed us that, starting in March (3-4 weeks away), it is mandatory to work in-office 3 days a week. COVID forced everyone to alter their entire lives, to adapt with the uncertainty, and to develop a way to continue living without being able to leave the house - over the past 2 years, majority of people did well with that arduous task, but it still took the better part of these past 2 years to create/perfect their new lives...so, with that in mind, Boeing makes working in the office for 3 days of the week mandatory, with only a 3-4 weeks' notice - hope no one has children in daycare/school, hope everyone with kids not old enough to attend daycare/school can find someone reliable, trustworthy, and under $15 an hour to watch their kids. Hmm, all my pros seem to turn into cons.
cons: The "training" you receive does more harm than good, there is no structure, no clear direction of where it's heading. The person training you schedules a slew of meetings throughout the week, followed by an endless number of slides and notes covering the assorted topics that will be covered - majority of those meetings end up getting cancelled/rescheduled/forgotten, which leaves you reading notes that you don't understand and with no direction. So, you ask management for help (which you quickly learn that management is not there to manage the team or to assist you with much, I think their only tasks are to "put out fires", and to email you asking why a supplier/program is not responding to your numerous emails - which should be common knowledge, apparently), and your manager will offer no guidance, but will pass the buck by telling you to go shadow someone from the team. After a month of "training", you are more confused than when you started, you have hundreds of pages of notes on systems/procedures that are foreign to you, but your manager decides to transfer a large amount of work under your name, and when you ask your manager how to do some of that work, their response is usually something along the lines of, "I am unaware of that process, I think you can find slides on how to do a work-movement in the shared drive (or some website)"; "I've never worked with those parts, but (teammate's name) knows what to do with those and where to send them next"; "I'm putting out a lot of fires, talk to the team and see who can help you"...to manage a team, shouldn't you have experience with what the team deals with - at the very least, an understanding of the team's scope? Long of the short of it, you only learn by becoming buried in work, searching for hours on how to complete your tasks, then slowly completing said task. If your manager: harasses you, discriminates against you, says you must come in and work while on PTO, lies to you about company policy, or mocks the severity of your request for PTO after a death in your family...it is futile to speak with HR about any and all of these issue because managers have the authority to "override the directions of HR" and will deem it mandatory to comply with their demands. Again, if you step back and look at the whole picture...you will notice how underpaid and undervalued you really are.

Some areas is OK, but recent promotions in Engineering management have significant issues: managers are put in place with zero technical knowledge or capability within their team. Many managers, senior managers, and even "chief engineers" haven't, and couldn't perform any of the tasks the engineers on their team do, and do not have enough technical knowledge to understand the engineering being released. Mistakes are made on a daily basis which affect the company bottom line, but unfortunately, the management are unaware that the mistake has been made! Promotions are significantly tilted in favor of self-promoters, and not based on capability or performance. Poor performance and mistakes are tolerated, accepted, and normal.

review_title: Company's Shift to Engineering Praised, but Challenges Persist
pros: The company is in the process of shifting back towards engineering excellence. From my perspective, this is a welcome change as it allows us to focus on delivering high quality products to our customers.

pros: - People (most are super nice) - Benefits (Hybrid work, Children LOA, 10% match 401k, Bonuses, work life flexibility)
cons: - Starting to push for more in office so will lose a lot of work/life flexibility. - Training for new hires could be better. I thought it would be a lot more structured when I started since it was such a big company.

pros: Best health insurance and other insurance-type benefits of any Fortune 100 company I’ve worked for. Ditto for the 401k match. Ditto for the education reimbursement benefits.
cons:
1) Most everyone I met was very uptight. Oddly hostile, defensive, and unprofessional reactions to even the simplest questions. Zero soft skills at all. 
2) Most people I met hadn’t worked anywhere else in the last 35 years. They had no ability or interest in examining other ways of working.
3) There was a weird (and very delusional) sense of hubris that their way of doing things is beyond reproach. So much arrogance.
4) Everything felt over-engineered, tedious, too structured, inefficient, conservative, and political. I felt like I was gaslit or patronized when I’d bring it up very basic observations that could remove unnecessary steps. After a while I just became a sycophant because that’s what reduced friction and made the day to day easier. 
5) I felt very out of place. I was easily 30 years younger than everyone I worked with. We had nothing in common, nothing to talk about, and very different viewpoints on most things. 

Boeing was not a fit for me, personally or professionally. I did learn some things there, but there was no way I was making a long term career out of that place. I felt like it led to disordered workplace habits that would be damaging to my career.  I felt so much relief when I left.

review_title: Management won't adapt to newer generations
pros: Healthcare is the only good thing
cons: By giving a 401k match instead of a pension or stock offering no one cares about the company's performance. There is no reason to stick at this company for more than 2 years anymore as the pay raises are non-existent and you will increase your salary by up to 50% by just finding a different company. Management does not listen to the employees when they bring up concerns. They completely disregarded the employee inputs on return to the office and are forcing everyone back even though they can still do their job from home. They even hired employees promising a work from home and then pulled the rug. Also, management will expect you to perform above your paygrade without providing any type of training. They preach that they will pair you with an experienced engineer, but they are too cheap to hire one so you'll be expected to perform as an experienced engineer. Also, why is the CEO getting paid 200 times the average employee when they are posting losses?

review_title: Overall Good Company that Needs Improvements
job_title: Lab Technician II in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The benefits are really good and it's also nice having a lab position that doesn't require a Bachelors degree but you probably need to know someone to get your foot in the door. The starting pay is good and there is a lot of opportunity for growth if you put the time in but it also 120% depends on who your manager is (see cons). IF your lab isn't slammed with work then the availability to flex your schedule is very nice. Potential for travel and overtime if that's a pro.
cons: Having a good manager is essential for growth. If they only care about themselves and looking good for upper management, then they are going to try and save as much money as possible. Meaning minimum bonuses, lack of promotions, etc. So while the starting pay is good, it could be stagnant for awhile. Work environment can be nice depending on your co workers just like anywhere. You can expect some engineers to be cliquey and more condescending to lower level positions but it really just depends on who you work with. Depending on the lab, there could be a lot of overtime and travel meaning poor work/life balance. Will mandate anything the government does. Cares more about keeping diversity % numbers vs work performance during lay offs.

The managers want people to be flexible by staying late daily up to 4 hours but dont return the favor by being flexible on preshift start times so that certain people can get home to their families. Also the pay is no longer competitive as starting out at fast food pays similar to what starting out as a mechanic putting people's lives in your hands pays.

pros: 1 interview and offer letter with in a week. They really need people
cons: I actually went through 2 interviews for inspector roles with Boeing. When offered a position with Boeing the wage offered was entry leveled, from what I was originally making and with a strong background experience. I was advised the union set the pay rate for a new hire and Boeing had to start there. Prior to being told the above, I was given the information to contact Boeings union, given union ID # to find out the pay wages for those positions I interviewed for, and to ask any questions I had. I was advised by the union the wages start from and their maximum amount. I asked in Boeings contract who was responsible for where employee wages start, I was advised that Boeing set the wages for this dollar amount to the max dollar amount and the union had no say in where Boeing sets its salary when hiring an employee. This is in there contact.

review_title: Upper Level Management Drives Team Burnout
pros: - Many opportunities for training, both on hours and off hours - Individual team dynamics are collaborative - Industry standard compensation (my offer was exactly average for my experience and industry average in the area) - Flexible hours if you're not directly supporting the factory line.
cons: - Training for each position not well laid out; you have to search out and schedule what you need. - Upper management pushes on schedule without really listening to the lower level people who know how long something should actually take, causing stress and burnout. - Gap in experience levels causes many single point failure opportunities where only one (or few) person on a team is qualified for a certain role, creating bottlenecks and burnout, and not enough extra time to train replacements or backup job roles.

job_title: Mechanical Systems Design and Analysis Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
1. US leadership is good and many time they are mislead buy the managers for Boeing India. but I think they too know some background how they work.
2. Most of the US leads are really supportive and encouraging.
cons:
1. BIE group has really biased leadership, in which they always encourage the people that they are close to them, and there no appreciation for the talented employees.

2. Managers grow much faster than the low level engineers, (5 years experience engineer might get promoted after 4 to 5 years from Level 1 to Level 4, but in the same time Manager will shift minimum 1 to 2 levels,) this says there is no value for the Technical side in Boeing.

3. Employee referral portals wont work in Boeing, they are just name sake. (internally they decide and take them, all fixed recruitment)

4. HR & first level manager always says your salaries are much better compared to market, but its not true in any ways, I don't know which market they are refereeing to? for the same position Airbus offers 40 to 50 % more.

5. They don't care about your salary until you putdown your papers, after that they will come to you and say, we can match to your expectations, you are really important to us...bla bla...

6. No value for long term staying employee, If a person joins Boeing 10 years ago, for the same skills and experience, new hire will get at-least 40 to 60% more,. just think about of the value to old employees.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
-Incredible level of flexibility and work life balance.

-A culture of compassion and understanding for family and life related events.

- Wonderful co-workers with managers and leadership who put your livelihood above anything else.

-Solid health care benefits, high 401(k) match, lucrative PTO and time flexing.

-Meaningful work and decent career flexibility.
cons:
- Abysmal IT infrastructure tied to horrific approval processes and lead times.

- Terrible salary progression for inexperienced and timid engineers.

- Endless chair-warmers who spew jargon for a living.

- Overly political leadership. Saving face here is often more important than owning up to problems.

- Not good for young creative thinkers willing to work their hearts out. Boeing is a very old, mature business, that focuses on stability. This is great for experienced engineers who maintain a family and are satisfied with their careers. However, this culture is soul crushing for young ambitious engineers.

review_title: Great company to work for but some sites are underpaid
pros: Good benefits. I've had excellent managers. Flexible work hours. Lots of PTO and paid holidays. Leadership is accommodating of work-life balance as long as you perform.  Long list of programs and fields that you can work but the company will prefer to transfer you without a raise/promotion.
cons:
Typical bureaucratic defense contractor mindsets: "customer implied that we need to do this mindless, non-applicable task so by-God we're gonna do it and ask questions later!". Win at all costs to long term reputation and product capabilities. Company does not make great aircraft, they make aircraft that meet the requirements and not a thing more (and those requirements are usually not well thought out).
Boeing is transparent enough to publish what they deem you to be worth (market reference).
Ridley Park (Philadelphia site) is grossly underpaid as a whole. Have been told by leadership that "no one at this site makes market reference". Consistently called a high performer, hand-selected for multiple high profile programs, yet paid ~80% of market reference because "the job is exciting". Suppose I need to work a more boring position to improve my salary.

review_title: A lot of problems but still better than most companies
pros:
Pretty great benefits even though the health insurance is more expensive every year. Amazing room for growth and obviously the tuition reimbursement is top tier.

Some departments are better than others. The first group I worked in at Boeing was amazing. I moved around a lot and definitely experienced some teams that were not that great.
cons:
One of the benefits of working at Boeing is that you can move around the company but a downside is that once someone leaves getting the approval to backfill takes forever. In the meantime the remaining employees are overloaded with work. 

Work life balance, especially during the pandemic, was almost nonexistent. If you were near your computer you were expected to be on call 24/7. If an email came in at 8 o’clock at night and you didn’t reply to it by 6 AM the next morning it was considered late and people would be pinging your manager to complain. 

It can also be very competitive and coworkers can sometimes be very cold as they try to maneuver their way up the corporate latter. Often times I felt like I was seen as competition.

pros: Couldn’t see myself satisfied long-term but good experience for career entry level
cons: Too pigeon holed into routine tasks

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros: Laid back- Work Life Balance Healthcare Benefits Mission Education Paid
cons: Salary is low compared to big tech and standard of living in Southern California. Facilities are old and makes employees feel undervalued. Strong push to come back into office. Lastly, the company kinds of inhibits you. We don’t use modern tool suites and skills that are transferable to other industries. Masters of PowerPoint.

review_title: What I've gleamed so far since working here
pros: Really good health insurance benefits. So big that a person has the opportunitiey to move around They care about mental health and are doing their best to help their employees and the employee's family to stay healthy. The donation matching and volunteer program. I like all the class, training, and learning opportunities we get as an employee of Boeing for free. There's no cap/very big cap on what Boeing will pay for if going back to school (depending on the degree). While I was in the ROTC and was about to be shipped off to boot camp, I talked to one of my managers and they told me that if your currently work for Boeing they do have a thing where they either hold your job or have a job waiting for you when you come back from deployment. I'm not sure if they still have this or all the details since I left ROTC before I was sent out, but it sounded like a great idea. If they have to give you the link slip because your the program you're on has ended or they're doing pay cuts, they do give you compensation and hold you in reserve for a certain amount of time when they can start hiring again and fast track you to the front of the line.
cons: It's common for people to leave the company and come back just to get a promotion. The ratio of women to men employees is appalling, let alone to leadership positions, and this doesn't even include how race plays a role. Stocks offered are better than some other companies I've seen in terms of variety, but still could be better.

pros:
The company management is rebounding from some bad years of poor stewardship/lack of accountability in the executive suite.

There are some fantastice employment opportunities coming up within the company - but depending on your field the compensation may not match industry standards (specifically for high tech fields like s/w engineering & design). That said, a Boeing career can be exceptionally rewarding.
cons: Processes are still slow to change, and the mindset shift needed for 21st century work is still not where it should be in the year 2022.

job_title: Contracts Procurement Agent in Everett, WA
pros: Starting wage for a new college graduate with no experience is high. Benefits are good - but getting worse year-over-year
cons: Terrible executive leadership who lines their own pockets with huge bonuses and stock options and could care less about all the individual contributors who make that possible. Unless you suck up to management there's zero possibility of promotion. Executive Leadership would rather you lie then tell them the truth about situations. Their 'Zero tolerance policy ' is not enforced at all. To the point that the federal government has filed formal charge of discrimination against three managers and the company and yet, those three managers still have jobs - yet the zero tolerance policy states immediate termination for discrimination of any kind. They assign unreasonable statements of work and then give you bad performance reviews. Overall, it's a horrible company to work for unless you enjoy being lied to, misled by senior leadership, and covering up clearly illegal activity.

pros: - Smart people work in DGS - Some people genuinely try to perform their best & improve for the better - Company too big to fail, so there is a lax attitude that can be either good or bad - Good work life balance - Interesting hackathons happen now and then - Work culture at some point was open and collaborative
cons: - Average compensation. They want loyal workers but don't reward loyalty - Individual accomplishment wont be rewarded. At best, you ll get a verbal thank you and some pride points worth a few dollars if lucky. That is reflected in bonuses as well. Bonuses are based on your group's performance. - Too much bureaucracy and outdated practices - High turnover, alot of people are abandoning ship - IT staff laid off 2 years ago, and with them left alot of tribal knowledge and know how. - Workspace very political. - Managers have great people skills, but behind the façade alot of contempt, backstabbing and politics goes on. Also same managers lack a concise vision, flip flop in their decisions and completely lack awareness in terms of competition. Some of them use their teams to "vote" on major decisions as means of diffusing responsibilities off their shoulders. Of course, said team doesn't have a say when/what those decisions are taken. If things go well, managers will take credit for their "leadership". As such, morale on many teams is very low. Some of those managers are down right delusional in their expectations (unrealistic expectations - one of the graveyard tombstones of failing projects). - Boeing overall is a sinking ship, all its upper managers care about is their bottom line. They don't have to try too hard because they know the US Gov will rescue it as its too big to fail. - Remote work is discouraged, and hybrid work is a "privilege'" that can be withdrawn at any given notice. Dinosaur management running a company to the ground as if its still 1989. - Good luck if you're a software engineer on some of their data science teams. You'll be siloed and work individually all while expected to be proficient in both data science and software disciplines as you shuffle through code written and deployed in subpar conditions. Any suggestions you suggest to make things better will fly over their heads because they are a "data science team". - Exit interviews are just formalities. Once you leave the company, you're treated like dirt. No thank yous or appreciation for the contributions you've put all this time.

review_title: This is not an engineering job like I thought...
pros: Not seasonally dependent or weather dependent. Not customer service based. Overtime available to those who can work that much. Holidays have team lunch. Most people are nice there. More or less autonomous.
cons:
Benefits: Are not benefits. They are ways to siphon your paycheck and pay health insurance companies. Which they conveniently switch at 6 months to completely different companies, so if you are going to apply here, elect to not do any benefits at least until 6 months are over (as you won't see any benefit and will just lose money). # Class Action?

Environment: Hot with little to no airflow. Very noisy--in fact deafening without earplugs. Toxic gases from burning plastics etc. and otherwise sanded parts dust everywhere and acetone. Close quarters. Loud bell-whip that goes off like every other hour at random times when workers stop moving or talk too much.

Mobility: No opportunity for advancement or pay raises. Moving to other departments is not inherently better.

Hiring Process: Took a long time with a bunch of redundant paperwork. Two drug screens, and harassment over Covid agenda (at the time of hire).

Pay: $15/hr doesn't cut it in So Cal. Periods switch from weekly to bi-weekly after 6 months.

review_title: Great Company w/ Great Benifits and Work Life Balance
job_title: Senior Engineering Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Boeing is a great company with exciting work and great job stability. The company has embraced hybrid work, and is offering competitive salaries. The benefits are great...health care premiums are a fraction of what other companies charge, 10% match on 401k, 4-6 weeks of PTO, 12+ weeks maternity/paternity leave, tuition for continuing education, and more. Engineers at the company also earn a premium on all overtime worked (although regular overtime is generally not required).
cons: It is a very large company, with very large processes, which can at time seem to be roadblocks to progress.

pros: Good bunch of coworkers to work with in each my different jobs at Boeing. Can move around Boeing easily if you're looking for a different finance position. It's great to be in the middle of things when you work in the factory.
cons: You're at times thrown into something over your head. I typically had to figure things out by myself. Over 13 years it was depressing as I saw my overall benefits decrease. Engineering and floor managers overworked so that they didn't have much time to look at their weekly financials. Boeing to me seems like they put some people in positions they aren't prepared for just to fill a quota. Training can be pretty bad as you're at times looking for the person who can answer your questions. There's a mentality in Hoeing Finance that once you do something once then you're considered to be the expert in that subject matter. :(

Easily the most annoying thing about working here since OK doesn't have unions like Seattle or STL. The other con is, because these programs are generally pretty long, and attrition rates are significant, the knowledge transfer process is almost non existent. review_title: Great place to work as a job, not as a passion
pros: Excellent work-life balance Excellent benefits (401k, healthcare, etc)
cons: Work is may not be as inspiring

pros:
Career growth for technical people in addition to the managerial track
Willingness to allow employees to learn new roles
Flexibility and understanding was a priority before and during COVID.
No need to worry if you get a bad manager, you will have a new one in a matter of months anyway.
Networking is easy.  Employees are moved around a lot, but not as often as managers.  It's very easy to meet a lot of people in a short amount of time whether you are virtual, hybrid, or onsite.
cons:
Management is moved around so often that it's impossible to get a meaningful performance review.  It prevents some people from getting raises and promotions.  I had 7 managers in the past 2 years.  Prior to that I had 5 managers in one year.

Similar to the management movement issue, employees can be moved around a lot too.  Not as often as managers, but very often.  This is both a positive and a negative.

The company randomly assigns employees to different locations with zero notice and does not allow time for things like finding transportation for themselves or childcare to accommodate the new location and schedule requirements.  Employees are told to suddenly report to a facility 2 to 3 hours away for unknown amounts of time, usually several months.  Sometimes this comes with a "start tomorrow" or "start next week" mandate.

If you have young kids, do not work here.  Upper management is actively forcing employees with young children out, no matter how valuable they are to the company.  Flexibility existed prior to COVID and during COVID.  Now that management has decided COVID no longer exists, there is no more flexibility.  We are being forced to spend our workdays in small conference rooms for socializing and sometimes for pizza parties instead of getting any actual work done.  This is also irrespective of critical meetings on the employees' schedules.  These events take precedence.

Employees were actively lied to about their working arrangements only to have them revoked the first week of the school year with less than two weeks of notice.  Teachers are on strike in several locations here but no one is allowed to work from home or take time to find alternative care solutions to watch their kids unless they call in sick, despite being allowed and required to work from home for most of the past two years. 

Many metrics showed that much of the company was much more effective, productive, and communicative working from home.  Now, despite being promised hybrid and virtual arrangements, everyone is required to go back to an office where they do not provide adequate equipment to do our jobs effectively and people walk around talking to everyone (not work related), preventing work from occurring.  Those of us who work across time zones are really suffering.  We are commuting when we should be in international meetings.  Management feels the need to suddenly strong-arm employees to get them to comply to all in-person mandates, zero flexibility exists anymore.  Unfortunately this is forcing a lot of very knowledgeable and critical employees into early retirement or to look for work elsewhere.

Boeing is actively advertising virtual and hybrid work offerings but when hired, employees are told they are 100% onsite or very close to that.  Don't believe any job advertisement that states it is hybrid or virtual.  It's simply not true.

review_title: Great company to work for IMO
pros:
- Work on bleeding edge technology
- Very meaningful work.  The job comes with a lot of responsibility.  Whether in the commercial or defense sector, people's lives are in your hands.  That's something I take very seriously and use as motivation.
- I've always had great bosses, laid back work atmosphere, have gotten along with almost all my coworkers
- You'll work with a lot of smart people
- Boeing is huge, so there's _always_ something new to work on, all over the US and world, if you're looking for an internal change.
- PTO seems generous.  You earn more at a faster rate as you become tenured.
cons:
- From what I understand, at least for software engineers, the base-pay compensation is lower than industry average (as of spring 2022).  Boeing even admits this.  Changes may be coming this year to correct that.  They've also recently began offering RSUs to close the gap.
- Boeing is huge, so there's a lot of red tape, lots of bureaucracy.  This is also something they're aware of and are striving to be more agile.

review_title: Big company with lots of red tape, but solid benefits and job security
job_title: Project Management Specialist III in Berkeley, MO
pros:
Good benefits, awesome 401k match, good tuition reimbursement, 1.5 weeks off at Christmas, good PTO, typically flexible schedule (but depends on the team). Relatively easy to move around in the company once you are in. 

Different programs might as well be different companies. Culture and expectations can vary so widely from team to team.

Job security, barely anyone gets fired from the Boeing company... just charge your time properly and use common sense.

There are a ton of discounts at varying companies and services for being a Boeing employee. Volunteer time/donation matching is great for supporting causes you care about.
cons:
Red Tape and bureaucracy can make you crazy. So many steps to get anything done, tons of delays. 

Easy to fall through the cracks for career development if you don't get a good manager or advocate for yourself. Taking another job from an internal posting will grow your salary and level way faster than staying on one team (sadly) so continuity of subject matter experts is not being built from the newer generation... but can you blame them? 

The company does training and encouragement for inclusion & no tolerance for sexual harassment, but it is a VERY big company, so each team/division is its own world. As a female engineer, I've experienced sexual harassment on 3 different teams, and only one instance where I escalated it to ethics myself did it result in the employee being investigated and eventually removed from the company.

If you have trouble... you probably have to escalate it to ethics yourself. Management might 'try' to help but likely won't do anything about complaints unless they are a great manager (semi-hard to come by here).

I call this place my golden handcuffs. My job is okay, I wish I could do more philanthropic/meaningful work... but the benefits and opportunity here is its own world and I'll probably never leave.

review_title: Decent - Not what it once was
pros:
Comparable union pay to other unions outside the company
Opportunity exists to move to different positions
Decent medical benefits, not the best, but not the worst
Company-match pension.   Company matches 50% of each 401k contribution (up to 8% of each paycheck contribution).
cons:
Production areas are often enormous high school atmospheres.  If you want a promotion, you can work hard and/or simply be the 2nd level manager's class pet. 

IAM751 union voted to remove all future pension plans.  The 401k alternate is nice, but is not a guarantee like the traditional pension is/was (example $100/month for each year of service, for life)

The Boeing careers website often asks for bachelor's degrees or higher, for many entry level salaried jobs that do not need that extensive educational background (example, if you can use the Microsoft Office suite proficiently, you are overly qualified to be a manufacturing engineer-planner or a project manager).  Prior work experience is not weighed the same as a 4-year non-technical degree.

job_title: Software Developer in El Segundo, CA
pros:
They hire at true entry-level and will take chances on individuals right out of university.
Ability to flex hours.
cons:
Boeing is desperately trying to pretend that they are the amazing aerospace company they used to be. But this snotty pretense lands hollow and employees get disillusioned quickly. 
Lack of innovation, they have a fear of modernizing and of change. They became angry and vindictive when anyone tries to use newer technology. 
It is like working in a factory, even as an engineer. You feel like you aren’t there to think, but to be a mindless. 
They care only about shareholders, not their products. Meaning everything is done cheaply, carelessly and without passion. 
Compensation is not keeping up with market.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: Boeing is a multi-disciplinary company, so you are not going to find yourself competing against 100,000 people who do the same thing. If you are good, focus on delivering quality, and have a growth mindset, you will find an unusual amount of advancement opportunity.
cons: Up until a few years ago the people running the company viewed engineering as a cost burden and spent the last two decades driving away talent and limiting new headcount to contractors and cheap overseas labor. Software Engineering was a particularly bad occupation, and the best managers knew how to hide talented software engineers under different job titles, like Systems Engineer, or even Electrical Engineer.

review_title: Overall Great Company to Work For
pros:
- Great benefits, up to 10% 401k match.
- Flexible time. Have a good work-life balance.
- Learning Together Program is amazing! Covers full tuition/fees for qualified STEM courses/programs, no spending limit. Makes earning ceritifcates for in-demand skills super easy.
- Really great pay scale for the aerospace/defense industry. If you’re an entry-level SWE expecting to make $100k+ off the bat, forget it. This isn’t Big Tech. You can get it at lvl 2. Otherwise, if you’re satisfied with having below that for 2 years, Boeing offers the best entry-lvl compensation you can get for this industry. The same goes for higher levels.
- Hybrid/Remote options. This is actually as much a pro as it is a con. Largely because this is gonna vary on what team you’re on, on what program. The biggest reason why this won’t work for a lot of teams (esp on the BDS side) is because of classified work that can only be done inside of cleared areas. But there is hybrid work available in BDS for some programs. Regarding other business units, BGS is confirmed to have remote options, and BCA is doing away with it (much to the dismay of the program teams). Though note, if you want purely remote work, (unless you get lucky) then working for an aerospace/defense company probably isn’t for you.
cons:
- The usual bureaucratic drama. But what company doesnt have that?
- Management is a hit or miss depending on your program/team. I’ve witnessed some really poor management in some programs with a huge lack of motivation and team spirit in their teams. This causes huge turnover among these programs and the cycle goes on. I’ve been in others with management that have gone above and beyond for their teams. They fight tooth and nail for their teams to get the compensation they deserve and show un-ending support for the professional growth of their team, with team spirit and moral being higher than ever. It just goes to show that Boeing as a large company is really a mixed bag and you never actually know which one you’re gonna get until you get there.

pros: Great benefits, free coffee, free safety equipment
cons: Awful management practices, safety requirements are overbearing and missing the point, and the workload is painfully mismanaged. No sense in rushing to get parts done when you KNOW there will be nothing left to do for 8 months out of the year because it happens EVERY year.

review_title: Used to be one of the best places to work, now it's mediocre at best.
pros:
Work/life balance is good.
Weekly workload is manageable most of the time.
Pay/benefits aren't industry leading anymore, but they're not 'terrible' either.
cons:
Difficult to get ahead due to lack of promotion opportunities. Pay has become mediocre and everyone's leaving the company for better paying jobs. 

Business tools and programs are horribly outdated. Most of the time, you'll be working in software programs older than you are. 

Company culture has gone full "woke" in the last couple of years, openly basing hiring and promotion decisions on gender and the color of your skin. 

The company tries to hold everyone back at a Level 2 or Level 3 pay code as long as possible, while giving them Level 4 and Level 5 work.

No clear vision from management, everything seems chaotic all the time. 

The company is made up of hundreds of little fiefdoms, each with their own set of overlapping processes and procedures. It's a huge bureaucratic mess and most of the time you're fighting the internal bureaucracy to get the smallest things done.

review_title: Great people and great company despite pandemic challenges
job_title: Senior Manager Engineering in Everett, WA
pros: Solid salary and benefits with bonus opportunities. Overall a great company with an admirable workforce. Most employees will go well out of their way to help others. Potential to build a large network over time with brilliant people. Plenty of opportunities to significantly contribute to many different meaningful projects. The global impact of contributing at Boeing cannot be understated.
cons: Salaries are solid, but don’t quite compete with Silicon Valley companies. On the other side of this pandemic, the company is still grappling with the culture/work style that will attract and retain the next generation of engineers and technical workforce. They have not established a consistent long-term framework for remote work and little has been done to update older office buildings. Other than restrooms, not much is done to keep office spaces clean. The company is highly driven to meet aggressive customer schedules while trying to staff teams. It can be extremely stressful and overloading depending on where one is in the company. This could slightly improve over time as aerospace tends to be cyclical in staffing levels.

review_title: BOEING is a great place to work for unless you’re in finance
job_title: Finance Integration Team Leader in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits, 401K match full, insurance, decent pay and incentives
cons:
Extreme lack of training or documentation, possibly because they allowed every acquisition they ever made stay on there own systems and none of them talk to each other, then they add constant change on top without standardization in processes or tools. It’s quite a cluster. Then senior leaders always seem to forget about all the complexities of the cost centers and expect you to wave a magic wand to pull all the data they need and want together in comprehensive packages with little to no warning. They implement “Enterprise Process & Tools”, but it’s in name only, because if the rev gen entities don’t want to use them they don’t have to and then they go off and develop something they want. SOOOOO MUCH WASTE!!!!!

Now apparently, it’s more important for 1st line managers to be able to manage up to the senior leaders, so they have demoted all the servant leaders…there’s basically no one supporting the finance employees. Work life balance is just a talking point when it comes to senior analysts…having there’s not enough time in a pay period to flex. Oh, and your salary, but required to log your time, but your not allowed OT. At the end of your pay period when you sign your time and you get the little fraud alert about recording time properly it’s next to impossible to log the actual time you worked when you’re not allowed to log OT.

Then the constant virtue signaling…makes the people that make up the largest % of their workforce feel like they aren’t valued at all.

review_title: Opportunities to learn, not a lot of support to do so
job_title: Industrial Engineer II in Everett, WA
pros: I've worked at Boeing for 2 years. This has been my first job out of college as an Industrial Engineer. I have had tons of opportunities to learn new skills and grow ones I already had, but was given virtually no other support to do so. I had an amazing first manager who worked hard to tackle hard topics during staff meetings, and genuinely listened to all sides of an argument/dispute. Managers like this are far and few between at Boeing.
cons:
When I first joined the company, I was given no training as to what I would be working on in my role. Instead, I was thrown directly into the fire and had to figure out EVERYTHING on my own. As a new engineer, this was difficult and frustrating. There are currently not many standards documents on how to execute the types of projects I was working, and subject matter experts are often very hard to find. I spend most of my time on wild goose chases trying to track down the correct people/info.

This might not be a Boeing particular thing, but they often treat their employees less like team members and more like company assets. By this I mean I was reorganized many times and was almost forced to transfer to another organization because the manager wanted my skills. I had no say in the matter. Company culture is also very old school, things move very slow and people resist change. During the pandemic I have not always felt safe working onsite as not many people mask and many employees are not vaccinated. Additionally, we were told that working hybrid/from home would be assessed at an individual level, but managers do not follow this for the sake of "fairness" to others on the team.

How management behaves varies a lot. Most mid management are expats who are parachuted in their positions without knowing the local culture or how the team and market operates. Higher management are fully expats. No progression what so ever for locals and glass ceiling is THICK.

If you are in the Joint ventures or subsidiaries,  it's even worse. Turn over is high and morale is low.

Pay is below market norm.

job_title: Systems Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I worked in systems at Boeing as a systems integrator for various programs. A few things really stood out to me. High priority was put on the employee/leadership relationship. I cannot remember a time when my manager did not have his or her door open for me to discuss career development, compensation, and workplace satisfaction. If meetings were to be rescheduled, it was done so with prompt notice and not at the last second. I was also exposed to a wide variety of hardware and software. For those who are looking to advance their careers on either of those fronts, systems integration is a great place to get started!
cons: This is not your "typical" engineering job. For those that want to do advanced design or analysis, this career path likely isn't for you. The role follows a model where the product design is mostly complete, with slight modifications needing to be added or taken away based on customer needs. Integration roles also routinely require people to be in labs, working hands on with equipment. The biggest negative of this role is that it's difficult to say the employee can maintain a schedule where working from home is consistent, even in today's far more flexible day in age.

pros: Great opportunities to do overtime and make extra money. My area is pretty good in the sense that the work is consistent and easy to learn over time and the crew is very supportive, both other inspectors and mechanics. The people really make or break the day, luckily I'm with a crew who are fun to be around and we all help each other out when the day gets busy.
cons: Occasional bad apples in management pushing for numbers and attempting to cut corners so that their number sheet looks good to their higher ups. Need to be mindful of how they interact with you as they could be subtly attempting to coerce you to buy off work that clearly isn't completed yet. Butting heads between different shifts, mostly 1st and 2nd.

review_title: Needs to be actually lean and agile, not LEAN and Agile
job_title: Electrical Systems Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Engineers get to see and do some really cool stuff. 10% 401K match, education benefits are great. Great for inclusiveness, Boeing has made a point to emphasize diversity (including race, gender identity, LGBT+, disabled, and veteran status, etc) There's a place for nearly anyone at Boeing.
cons: Slow to design and build anything, bogged down by meetings and spread too thinly across myriad sites. Inexplicably targeted dual monitors as the sole cost overrun for 2022, asking new hire engineers to accept worse hardware working for one of the largest firms on the planet than most of us have at home.

pros: Most (but not all) of my managers have been people who have a technical background, often in the same area they are managing. Most have been very understanding and accommodating of work-life balance. Paid parental leave is a major benefit. Plenty of opportunities within the company.
cons: Promotions can be hard to come by and dependent on how proactive your manager is. Many people move around within the company to climb the ladder but excelling in a job you enjoy isn't always rewarded.

job_title: Contracts Regional Director in Seattle, WA
pros: Benefits are ok, although the vision plan (Davis Vision) is horrible. Pay is ok. It is interesting work and we build neat products
cons: -They punish long time employees, the more you make the more of the health cost you pay. When they switched, my health insurance cost tripled in one year. -They dont promote capability and experience. -Compensation wise, they only take care of executives (they are rewarded handsomely, not so much for everyone else) -They promote too many managers/execs with the wrong quality's, too many tyrants running the place -zero work/life balance, expected to take laptop on vacation. no unplugging.

pros: Pension scheme - they double your contributions.
cons: Management - top heavy - the mid level management do not make enough impact to warrant their inflated salaries, company cars and bonus'. Little to no investment in employees with regards to formal training. 'Raise a business case'. Military mentality (Ex Army and RAF middle aged men every where) between management is archaic and out dated. Creates a stressful, pressurized, no trust environment. Dreadful work life balance - HR always involved - where's the trust? The business takes from individuals but doesn't give back. Ethics - Managers receiving extreme bonus payouts. Exit process - Having to have my exit interview with a manager who was responsible for me leaving. Constant re-orgs and redundancies - Managers some how worming their way out of the process in to equally non impacting roles like 'Optimisation' and 'Supply Chain'. Lunch and Learn 'incentives' - I am having my lunch!

Forced stack ranking of bottom 10% of employees, outsourcing entire groups (including engineering) and functions, moving entire teams to other states. Leadership is entirely focused on their next quarters bonuses and will be leaving before major impacts are visible to their short term cost cutting. Leaders are not from Boeing and do not care about the people that work here. Are there development projects or are the current designs being milked into oblivion, with no future?  Meanwhile Airbus and new competitors will continue to take market share. Thus experienced analysts, low and mid tier managers are leaving for greener pastures.

Management doesn't seem to care, and if they do its misplaced on the wrong things as a result of likely blindly following those above them. I have lost a lot of trust and faith in the decisions this company now makes. job_title: Electrical Engineer II in El Segundo, CA
pros: Lots of opportunities for growth. The entire El Segundo site is very busy and has been for a while, and engineers are expected to tackle projects that may be above their pay grade. Many projects are high-visibility and can lead to upper-management recognition if completed successfully. Paperwork, process, and red-tape can be frustrating, but the culture at the El Segundo site is not a typical "slow-paced defense company culture". The work can be challenging and engaging depending on the team you are on. All together, the pay/benefits are solid for the area. The base pay may be lower than some competitors, but once the healthcare costs/contributions, retirement contributions, overtime pay, and bonus (depends on year) are factored in, the pay can be good! PTO accrual is very generous, but it is frequently a challenge to get the opportunity to use it with project timelines. On-site gyms in the SoCal area are nice, but often crowded at peak times.
cons: Burn-out is common due to aggressive timelines on certain teams within the site, especially when supporting projects needed for production.

review_title: The good and the Bad from my Work Experience at Boeing
job_title: Airframe Mechanic in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Good starting pay, good benefits including health and education. Camaraderie is amazing with this site basically forming a second family. The hours started out as good, the work is fulfilling to me.
cons: In this particular job, management is offsite, so they have no visibility on how you do your work. We are treated as mediocre, though we recently received very high accolades on an inspection. Our autonomy was taken from us.

review_title: Management Can Overrule HR & Demand Your "Obedience"
pros: Benefits & pay - the only reason Boeing management has employees to neglect. At first, it seems like Boeing pays well, but if you take a step back and look at the entire picture, you can easily see that you are underpaid, overworked, and undervalued. Being salaried at $60k+ starting out looks and sounds great, but you are only salaried IF it benefits Boeing, meaning: if you work 75 hours during the pay period, you are only paid for 75 hours, but if you work 90+ hours during the pay period, you are only paid for 80 hours, no overtime - this was a first, I'm salary and I clock in and out. Working remote was a pro, but the higher-ups have made it clear that they are going to get rid of that possibility: management informed us that, starting in March (3-4 weeks away), it is mandatory to work in-office 3 days a week. COVID forced everyone to alter their entire lives, to adapt with the uncertainty, and to develop a way to continue living without being able to leave the house - over the past 2 years, majority of people did well with that arduous task, but it still took the better part of these past 2 years to create/perfect their new lives...so, with that in mind, Boeing makes working in the office for 3 days of the week mandatory, with only a 3-4 weeks' notice - hope no one has children in daycare/school, hope everyone with kids not old enough to attend daycare/school can find someone reliable, trustworthy, and under $15 an hour to watch their kids. Hmm, all my pros seem to turn into cons.
cons: The "training" you receive does more harm than good, there is no structure, no clear direction of where it's heading. The person training you schedules a slew of meetings throughout the week, followed by an endless number of slides and notes covering the assorted topics that will be covered - majority of those meetings end up getting cancelled/rescheduled/forgotten, which leaves you reading notes that you don't understand and with no direction. So, you ask management for help (which you quickly learn that management is not there to manage the team or to assist you with much, I think their only tasks are to "put out fires", and to email you asking why a supplier/program is not responding to your numerous emails - which should be common knowledge, apparently), and your manager will offer no guidance, but will pass the buck by telling you to go shadow someone from the team. After a month of "training", you are more confused than when you started, you have hundreds of pages of notes on systems/procedures that are foreign to you, but your manager decides to transfer a large amount of work under your name, and when you ask your manager how to do some of that work, their response is usually something along the lines of, "I am unaware of that process, I think you can find slides on how to do a work-movement in the shared drive (or some website)"; "I've never worked with those parts, but (teammate's name) knows what to do with those and where to send them next"; "I'm putting out a lot of fires, talk to the team and see who can help you"...to manage a team, shouldn't you have experience with what the team deals with - at the very least, an understanding of the team's scope? Long of the short of it, you only learn by becoming buried in work, searching for hours on how to complete your tasks, then slowly completing said task. If your manager: harasses you, discriminates against you, says you must come in and work while on PTO, lies to you about company policy, or mocks the severity of your request for PTO after a death in your family...it is futile to speak with HR about any and all of these issue because managers have the authority to "override the directions of HR" and will deem it mandatory to comply with their demands. Again, if you step back and look at the whole picture...you will notice how underpaid and undervalued you really are.

review_title: Management is lost, out of touch, unlikely to improve. Inadequate technical leadership in Management ranks.

Many managers, senior managers, and even "chief engineers" haven't, and couldn't perform any of the tasks the engineers on their team do, and do not have enough technical knowledge to understand the engineering being released. Mistakes are made on a daily basis which affect the company bottom line, but unfortunately, the management are unaware that the mistake has been made! Promotions are significantly tilted in favor of self-promoters, and not based on capability or performance. Poor performance and mistakes are tolerated, accepted, and normal.

pros: Best health insurance and other insurance-type benefits of any Fortune 100 company I’ve worked for. Ditto for the 401k match. Ditto for the education reimbursement benefits.
cons:
1) Most everyone I met was very uptight. Oddly hostile, defensive, and unprofessional reactions to even the simplest questions. Zero soft skills at all. 
2) Most people I met hadn’t worked anywhere else in the last 35 years. They had no ability or interest in examining other ways of working.
3) There was a weird (and very delusional) sense of hubris that their way of doing things is beyond reproach. So much arrogance.
4) Everything felt over-engineered, tedious, too structured, inefficient, conservative, and political. I felt like I was gaslit or patronized when I’d bring it up very basic observations that could remove unnecessary steps. After a while I just became a sycophant because that’s what reduced friction and made the day to day easier. 
5) I felt very out of place. I was easily 30 years younger than everyone I worked with. We had nothing in common, nothing to talk about, and very different viewpoints on most things. 

Boeing was not a fit for me, personally or professionally. I did learn some things there, but there was no way I was making a long term career out of that place. I felt like it led to disordered workplace habits that would be damaging to my career.  I felt so much relief when I left.

pros: At Boeing you can work all around the world and are exposed to some of the most incredible technologies in the world. I had some of the best experiences with some of the most incredible jobs you probably wouldn't imagine.
cons: It's all about the shareholder now. Its about the bottom line and employees at all levels are just a means to an end. Poor ethics, flat out lying at the highest levels, corruption, affairs, cover ups, and just bad ethics. I worked at the highest and lowest levels of the company and as you go higher up the ladder the more the company is less appealing -- unless your ethics are as low as those around you.

review_title: Management won't adapt to newer generations
pros: Healthcare is the only good thing
cons: By giving a 401k match instead of a pension or stock offering no one cares about the company's performance. There is no reason to stick at this company for more than 2 years anymore as the pay raises are non-existent and you will increase your salary by up to 50% by just finding a different company. Management does not listen to the employees when they bring up concerns. They completely disregarded the employee inputs on return to the office and are forcing everyone back even though they can still do their job from home. They even hired employees promising a work from home and then pulled the rug. Also, management will expect you to perform above your paygrade without providing any type of training. They preach that they will pair you with an experienced engineer, but they are too cheap to hire one so you'll be expected to perform as an experienced engineer. Also, why is the CEO getting paid 200 times the average employee when they are posting losses?

review_title: Overall Good Company that Needs Improvements
job_title: Lab Technician II in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The benefits are really good and it's also nice having a lab position that doesn't require a Bachelors degree but you probably need to know someone to get your foot in the door. The starting pay is good and there is a lot of opportunity for growth if you put the time in but it also 120% depends on who your manager is (see cons). IF your lab isn't slammed with work then the availability to flex your schedule is very nice. Potential for travel and overtime if that's a pro.
cons: Having a good manager is essential for growth. If they only care about themselves and looking good for upper management, then they are going to try and save as much money as possible. Meaning minimum bonuses, lack of promotions, etc. So while the starting pay is good, it could be stagnant for awhile. Work environment can be nice depending on your co workers just like anywhere. You can expect some engineers to be cliquey and more condescending to lower level positions but it really just depends on who you work with. Depending on the lab, there could be a lot of overtime and travel meaning poor work/life balance. Will mandate anything the government does. Cares more about keeping diversity % numbers vs work performance during lay offs.

pros: The Pay is good, the insurance is ok and the work isn't extremely difficult although certain jobs are harder on parts of your body than others.

The managers stare at Facebook for 7 hours and then spend the final hour telling mechanics how lazy they are for not completing 12 hours of work in 8 hours. The managers want people to be flexible by staying late daily up to 4 hours but dont return the favor by being flexible on preshift start times so that certain people can get home to their families. Also the pay is no longer competitive as starting out at fast food pays similar to what starting out as a mechanic putting people's lives in your hands pays.

pros: 1 interview and offer letter with in a week. They really need people
cons: I actually went through 2 interviews for inspector roles with Boeing. When offered a position with Boeing the wage offered was entry leveled, from what I was originally making and with a strong background experience. I was advised the union set the pay rate for a new hire and Boeing had to start there. Prior to being told the above, I was given the information to contact Boeings union, given union ID # to find out the pay wages for those positions I interviewed for, and to ask any questions I had. I was advised by the union the wages start from and their maximum amount. I asked in Boeings contract who was responsible for where employee wages start, I was advised that Boeing set the wages for this dollar amount to the max dollar amount and the union had no say in where Boeing sets its salary when hiring an employee. This is in there contact.

pros: Good starting salary. Huge amount of resources in terms of softwares and subject matter experts. There's always someone on your team or another, as they all work close together, that is willing to help or educate you on a process or practice. 9/80 schedule is really nice. Everyone there is really kind.
cons: After three years my base salary only rose by 9%. Been a rough few years for Boeing so the financial benefits have stalled. Scope of each team is so vast that you work on one type of project for 4 months and then move onto something completely different, which can be a "pro" but I never felt like I mastered or became comfortable at any one skill or software over my 3 years there.

review_title: Upper Level Management Drives Team Burnout
pros: - Many opportunities for training, both on hours and off hours - Individual team dynamics are collaborative - Industry standard compensation (my offer was exactly average for my experience and industry average in the area) - Flexible hours if you're not directly supporting the factory line.
cons: - Training for each position not well laid out; you have to search out and schedule what you need. - Upper management pushes on schedule without really listening to the lower level people who know how long something should actually take, causing stress and burnout. - Gap in experience levels causes many single point failure opportunities where only one (or few) person on a team is qualified for a certain role, creating bottlenecks and burnout, and not enough extra time to train replacements or backup job roles.

review_title: Culture needs to change in Boeing India !!!
job_title: Mechanical Systems Design and Analysis Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
1. US leadership is good and many time they are mislead buy the managers for Boeing India. but I think they too know some background how they work.
2. Most of the US leads are really supportive and encouraging.
cons:
1. BIE group has really biased leadership, in which they always encourage the people that they are close to them, and there no appreciation for the talented employees.

2. Managers grow much faster than the low level engineers, (5 years experience engineer might get promoted after 4 to 5 years from Level 1 to Level 4, but in the same time Manager will shift minimum 1 to 2 levels,) this says there is no value for the Technical side in Boeing.

3. Employee referral portals wont work in Boeing, they are just name sake. (internally they decide and take them, all fixed recruitment)

4. HR & first level manager always says your salaries are much better compared to market, but its not true in any ways, I don't know which market they are refereeing to? for the same position Airbus offers 40 to 50 % more.

5. They don't care about your salary until you putdown your papers, after that they will come to you and say, we can match to your expectations, you are really important to us...bla bla...

6. No value for long term staying employee, If a person joins Boeing 10 years ago, for the same skills and experience, new hire will get at-least 40 to 60% more,. just think about of the value to old employees.

review_title: Great company to work for but some sites are underpaid
pros: Good benefits. I've had excellent managers. Flexible work hours. Lots of PTO and paid holidays. Leadership is accommodating of work-life balance as long as you perform.  Long list of programs and fields that you can work but the company will prefer to transfer you without a raise/promotion.
cons:
Typical bureaucratic defense contractor mindsets: "customer implied that we need to do this mindless, non-applicable task so by-God we're gonna do it and ask questions later!". Win at all costs to long term reputation and product capabilities. Company does not make great aircraft, they make aircraft that meet the requirements and not a thing more (and those requirements are usually not well thought out).
Boeing is transparent enough to publish what they deem you to be worth (market reference).
Ridley Park (Philadelphia site) is grossly underpaid as a whole. Have been told by leadership that "no one at this site makes market reference". Consistently called a high performer, hand-selected for multiple high profile programs, yet paid ~80% of market reference because "the job is exciting". Suppose I need to work a more boring position to improve my salary.

review_title: A lot of problems but still better than most companies
pros:
Pretty great benefits even though the health insurance is more expensive every year. Amazing room for growth and obviously the tuition reimbursement is top tier.

Some departments are better than others. The first group I worked in at Boeing was amazing. I moved around a lot and definitely experienced some teams that were not that great.
cons:
One of the benefits of working at Boeing is that you can move around the company but a downside is that once someone leaves getting the approval to backfill takes forever. In the meantime the remaining employees are overloaded with work. 

Work life balance, especially during the pandemic, was almost nonexistent. If you were near your computer you were expected to be on call 24/7. If an email came in at 8 o’clock at night and you didn’t reply to it by 6 AM the next morning it was considered late and people would be pinging your manager to complain. 

It can also be very competitive and coworkers can sometimes be very cold as they try to maneuver their way up the corporate latter. Often times I felt like I was seen as competition.

Lastly, the company kinds of inhibits you. We don’t use modern tool suites and skills that are transferable to other industries. Masters of PowerPoint.

review_title: What I've gleamed so far since working here
pros: Really good health insurance benefits. So big that a person has the opportunitiey to move around They care about mental health and are doing their best to help their employees and the employee's family to stay healthy. The donation matching and volunteer program. I like all the class, training, and learning opportunities we get as an employee of Boeing for free. There's no cap/very big cap on what Boeing will pay for if going back to school (depending on the degree). While I was in the ROTC and was about to be shipped off to boot camp, I talked to one of my managers and they told me that if your currently work for Boeing they do have a thing where they either hold your job or have a job waiting for you when you come back from deployment. I'm not sure if they still have this or all the details since I left ROTC before I was sent out, but it sounded like a great idea. If they have to give you the link slip because your the program you're on has ended or they're doing pay cuts, they do give you compensation and hold you in reserve for a certain amount of time when they can start hiring again and fast track you to the front of the line.
cons: It's common for people to leave the company and come back just to get a promotion. The ratio of women to men employees is appalling, let alone to leadership positions, and this doesn't even include how race plays a role. Stocks offered are better than some other companies I've seen in terms of variety, but still could be better.

pros: Good pay Networking Aerospace Opportunities for advancement

pros: - Smart people work in DGS - Some people genuinely try to perform their best & improve for the better - Company too big to fail, so there is a lax attitude that can be either good or bad - Good work life balance - Interesting hackathons happen now and then - Work culture at some point was open and collaborative
cons: - Average compensation. They want loyal workers but don't reward loyalty - Individual accomplishment wont be rewarded. At best, you ll get a verbal thank you and some pride points worth a few dollars if lucky. That is reflected in bonuses as well. Bonuses are based on your group's performance. - Too much bureaucracy and outdated practices - High turnover, alot of people are abandoning ship - IT staff laid off 2 years ago, and with them left alot of tribal knowledge and know how. - Workspace very political. - Managers have great people skills, but behind the façade alot of contempt, backstabbing and politics goes on. Also same managers lack a concise vision, flip flop in their decisions and completely lack awareness in terms of competition. Some of them use their teams to "vote" on major decisions as means of diffusing responsibilities off their shoulders. Of course, said team doesn't have a say when/what those decisions are taken. If things go well, managers will take credit for their "leadership". As such, morale on many teams is very low. Some of those managers are down right delusional in their expectations (unrealistic expectations - one of the graveyard tombstones of failing projects). - Boeing overall is a sinking ship, all its upper managers care about is their bottom line. They don't have to try too hard because they know the US Gov will rescue it as its too big to fail. - Remote work is discouraged, and hybrid work is a "privilege'" that can be withdrawn at any given notice. Dinosaur management running a company to the ground as if its still 1989. - Good luck if you're a software engineer on some of their data science teams. You'll be siloed and work individually all while expected to be proficient in both data science and software disciplines as you shuffle through code written and deployed in subpar conditions. Any suggestions you suggest to make things better will fly over their heads because they are a "data science team". - Exit interviews are just formalities. Once you leave the company, you're treated like dirt. No thank yous or appreciation for the contributions you've put all this time.

review_title: This is not an engineering job like I thought...
pros: Not seasonally dependent or weather dependent. Not customer service based. Overtime available to those who can work that much. Holidays have team lunch. Most people are nice there. More or less autonomous.
cons:
Benefits: Are not benefits. They are ways to siphon your paycheck and pay health insurance companies. Which they conveniently switch at 6 months to completely different companies, so if you are going to apply here, elect to not do any benefits at least until 6 months are over (as you won't see any benefit and will just lose money). # Class Action?

Environment: Hot with little to no airflow. Very noisy--in fact deafening without earplugs. Toxic gases from burning plastics etc. and otherwise sanded parts dust everywhere and acetone. Close quarters. Loud bell-whip that goes off like every other hour at random times when workers stop moving or talk too much.

Mobility: No opportunity for advancement or pay raises. Moving to other departments is not inherently better.

Hiring Process: Took a long time with a bunch of redundant paperwork. Two drug screens, and harassment over Covid agenda (at the time of hire).

Pay: $15/hr doesn't cut it in So Cal. Periods switch from weekly to bi-weekly after 6 months.

pros: Boeing is a great company with exciting work and great job stability. The company has embraced hybrid work, and is offering competitive salaries. Engineers at the company also earn a premium on all overtime worked (although regular overtime is generally not required).
